name: Lab 1: The Nature of Science

description:
Lab 3 ESCI 240 - Temperature, Pressure, and Density

✓ Auto-saved

Lab 3 ESCI 240 - Temperature, Pressure, and Density in the Atmosphere

Total: 30 Points

⚠ Please complete all required fields before submitting:
    1. Using the simple rule that for every 5.6 km you ascend, there is approximately one-half of the atmospheric mass above, indicate the percentages in the table below * (2 pts)
    % Above Height (km)
    22.4
    16.8
    11.2
    5.6
    100% Sea Level
    2. Curve letter below accurately represents the information from the table above * (3 pts)
    Select the curve letter: -- Select a curve -- Curve A Curve B Curve C Curve D

    Background: Barometric pressure reflects the weight of the atmosphere above a point. There is also a close relationship between height and atmospheric pressure. We can assume that 100% of the atmospheric mass lies above sea level and exerts a pressure of approximately 1000 millibars (mb). Since atmospheric mass at 5.6 km is 50% of its sea-level value, the pressure at this height would be half of that exerted at sea level (roughly 500 mb).

    Question 3 - Pressure and Atmosphere Estimates

    3a. The height of a cruising airliner (11 km) * (2 pts)
    mb with approximately % of the atmosphere remaining above
    3b. The top of Mt. Everest (8.85 km) * (2 pts)
    mb with approximately % of the atmosphere remaining above
    3c. Denver, CO (1.6 km) * (2 pts)
    mb with approximately % of the atmosphere remaining above

    Background: Recalling that the rate at which the temperature decreases with altitude is known as lapse rate, the atmosphere can be broken up into layers based on lapse-rate behavior. When averaged over all seasons, air temperature is 15°C at Earth's surface and decreases by 6.5°C per kilometer in the lowest 11 kilometers (km). This is the average lapse rate. The resulting temperature plot is known as the "standard atmosphere".

    The following chart shows three plots of temperature with altitude in the atmosphere. One represents the temperature profile on a cold day for a station in Alaska, another for a warm day for a station in the tropics, and the last represents the standard atmosphere.

    4. Station _______ has the highest surface temperature * (1 pt)
    5. Station _______ has the highest temperature at 10 km * (1 pt)
    6. Station _______ has the highest temperature at 14 km * (1 pt)

    Note: As the plots indicate, there are layers in the troposphere where temperature increases with height. Since this is the opposite of normal, such layers are called inversion layers.

    7. The ______ color plot has an inversion layer * (2 pts)
    Color: that starts at km and ends at km

    Definition: The tropopause marks the top of the troposphere and is defined as the level where temperature stops decreasing with height.

    8. The tropopause for the red station * (2 pts)
    Occurs at km at a temperature of °C
    9. The tropopause for the blue station * (2 pts)
    Occurs at km at a temperature of °C
    10. The tropopause for the magenta station * (2 pts)
    Occurs at km at a temperature of °C
    11. The _____ color plot represents Alaska * (1 pt)
    12. The _____ color plot represents the tropics * (1 pt)
    13. What relationship do you see between average tropospheric temperature and the height of the tropopause? * (3 pts)
    14. In your own words, describe how air pressure, density, and temperature vary with height in the troposphere * (3 pts)
    💾 Save Progress ✓ Submit Lab

name: Ch 13 Quiz

description:
This discussion is designed to get you thinking about science and human nature when it comes to making decisions. Be sure you address each numbered item in your discussion!  If you have any questions, please let me know!

 

Please read the following article: AcceptDefeat122109.pdf

Answer the following:

1. What type of interaction allowed the diverse lab to solve a problem in 10 minutes when it took the experts weeks to solve the same problem?  

2. What did these interactions force them to do?

The article states "When it comes to interpreting our experiments, we see what we want to see and disregard the rest." 

3. Give an example where someone you know "saw only what they wanted to see" when interpreting something that happened in their life.  Did it bother you and why?

4. How can you safeguard yourself from “only seeing what you want to see”?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

When we see a piece of information and make a conclusion from it, it is important to know what assumptions we are making.  An assumption is something we do not know to be true for sure, but we take for granted that it is.  For instance in science, we assume that the physical rules of the world never change.  Gravity is constant, the sun will come up each morning, that sort of thing.  But what if the physical rules of the world changed tomorrow?  Every scientific "fact" could become wrong!  

Describe an example of when you have been “surprised” in your recent past.   

5. What was the surprise? What assumption you were making that led to your surprise?

6. Why did you make this assumption?

7. What will this surprise help you to consider when you encounter a similar situation in the future?

 

Two examples from me:

 

My organization advertised for a job in my section, but to my surprise it was limited only to internal candidates.  My assumption was that since the most qualified candidates were all external to the organization, that they would make the job available to those candidates.  In the future I will remember that finding the most qualified candidate is not necessarily the only consideration when hiring for jobs.

 

I got a large package from amazon.com, and to my surprise there was only a small box of granola bars inside and nothing else.  My assumption was that Amazon would not waste packaging due to its extra cost and the fact that it makes them look incompetent.  In the future I will remember that there are other costs involved in shipping goods, and that companies may not have optimized their logistical methods before they offer delivery.
name: Discussion 1: Thinking Scientifically

discussion_topic.title: Discussion 1: Thinking Scientifically

description:
Climate change (defined as the change in expected weather over periods greater than 30 years) is undoubtedly the most visible problem in the atmospheric sciences at this time.  Increasing amounts of effort are being devoted to studying not only how the climate system works, but projecting how it will change in the future based on anticipated natural and human factors.  The climate system is very complex so that predicting the future climate, and its impacts in different regions of the world, is challenging to say the least.  Since this is such an important issue right now, it makes sense for this class to examine climate change science more thoroughly.

Please answer the following:

1) Name two natural causes of climate change and explain how they work to change the climate

2) Name two man-made causes of climate change and explain how they work to change the climate

3) Name one method scientists use to attribute climate changee to a cause (i.e. since many factors control climate, how do we know which causes lead to which changes), and one assumption that underlies that attribution method.

4) Discuss your impressions of climate change science before this class.  What had you read or heard, and what was your reaction?
name: Discussion 2: The science of Climate Change

discussion_topic.title: Discussion 2: The science of Climate Change
discussion_topic.message:
Climate change (defined as the change in expected weather over periods greater than 30 years) is undoubtedly the most visible problem in the atmospheric sciences at this time.  Increasing amounts of effort are being devoted to studying not only how the climate system works, but projecting how it will change in the future based on anticipated natural and human factors.  The climate system is very complex so that predicting the future climate, and its impacts in different regions of the world, is challenging to say the least.  Since this is such an important issue right now, it makes sense for this class to examine climate change science more thoroughly.

Please answer the following:

1) Name two natural causes of climate change and explain how they work to change the climate

2) Name two man-made causes of climate change and explain how they work to change the climate

3) Name one method scientists use to attribute climate changee to a cause (i.e. since many factors control climate, how do we know which causes lead to which changes), and one assumption that underlies that attribution method.

4) Discuss your impressions of climate change science before this class.  What had you read or heard, and what was your reaction?

description:
Everyone has access to the same information about climate change science that we discussed last time.  However, people reach very different conclusions about what, if anything, should be done about climate change.

Please complete the following:

Explain two reasons that a person might conclude strong governmental action is needed to combat climate change?

Explain two reasons that a person might conclude strong governmental action is not needed to combat climate change?

Given your answers for the above questions and for the previous discussion board, what do you think is more difficult--the science behind climate change, or the politics of deciding what to do about it?  Explain.

Give your own personal opinion of what policies should be put in place to deal with climate change.  Or, if you feel no policies should be put in place, explain why.  Then, when you do your discussion responses to other students, you MUST respond to and be critical of the opinion they gave.  This is to practice being critical in a constructive and friendly manner, which is a vital skill.  If you have a strong opinion about this issue, this would be a great time to practice being critical from the opposite point of view--find someone who largely agrees with you and critique what they said.

You are not required to do so, but if you engage in a quality back and forth discussion, I will give bonus points.

Reference: http://conflict911.com/guestconflict/arguecontext.htm
name: Discussion 3: The Politics of Climate Change

description:
As we have learned in this course, the science of weather prediction is imperfect.  Although warnings are usually issued before bad storms occur, sometimes the storms fail to materialize or strike somewhere else nearby, leading to a "false alarm" when someone was warned about weather that did not occur.  Unfortunately, if enough of these false alarms occur, people stop heeding the warning and then when the storm does strike, disastrous results can occur (i.e. Katrina).

Please answer the following:

Describe an instance in your life where weather caused a major impact to you or someone close to you.
How do you personally respond to weather watches/warnings?  Note: no penalty for honesty!
Given that weather warnings are always going to have some uncertainty, what should society do differently to make them more effective?  If the answer is nothing, explain.
name: Discussion 4: Human Response to Weather Warnings

discussion_topic.title: Discussion 4: Human Response to Weather Warnings
